div.head: SCOTLAND.
div.p: THe realme of Scotland hath England on the Å¿outh Å¿yde therof & on all other Å¿ydes els, it is ennyroned with the maine Ocean, on the north Å¿yde it hath the Iles called the Orcades & on the weÅ¿t the Hibrides, all Å¿ubjeÄ‡t vnto Scotland. And albeit it bee not Å¿o frute full as England, yet is the land aboundantly furniÅ¿hed with cattel, & the Å¿ea with fiÅ¿h, & in it are many thinges very Å¿trange & wounderfull.Â Â Â Â Â Â In GlaÅ¿co is a lake, one parte whereof frieÅ¿eth in winter but the other parte doth neuer friÅ¿e. In CarikÂ are Oxen whoÅ¿e far is neuer hard, but alwayes Å¿oft & oily.Â Â Â Â Â Â In the prouince of CoylÂ or Kyle about ten myles from the towne of AerÂ here is a Å¿tone 12 foote in height & 30 in length called the deaf Å¿tone, for albeit neuer Å¿o great noiÅ¿e bee made on the one Å¿yde, on the other Å¿yde it cannot bee heard, vnieffe a man Å¿tand farr of, for Å¿o may it bee deÅ¿cerned, or els not.Â Â Â Â Â Â In Lennox is a lake called LawmondÂ beeing about 14 myles in length & 8 in bredth having in it thirty Iles, in this lake are three thinges woorthy of note. There are finleÅ¿Å¿ Å¿iÅ¿hes, & of a good taÅ¿te. There are fleeting Iles that with thee wynde are moued & driuen to & fro, And Å¿omtymes no wynde blowing, the water becometh Å¿o rough that the paÅ¿Å¿engers are in great danger to bee drowned yf they cannot Å¿peedely get to land. In Argadia (as is reported) groweth a Å¿tone which beeing put to Å¿traw or Å¿tubble wil kindle & Å¿et the Å¿ame on fyre.Â Â Â Â Â Â In BurquhamÂ is a caue wherein water falling it turneth into whyte Å¿tones, & in this prouince no rattes are found. In the Å¿ea at the mouth of the riuer of Forth is a highÂ rock out of the top whereof iÅ¿Å¿ueth a fountaine of freÅ¿he water. About 10 mylesÂ from Edenbourgh is a fountaine, on the water whereof drops of oyle are fonud, theÂ which oile is medicinable. In ClidiÅ¿daleÂ is a myne of Gold, & another of azure, and inÂ the muÅ¿cles and Å¿helfiÅ¿h on the Å¿hore of Scotland pearles are found.Â

Ortelius, Abraham, 1527-1598. An epitome of Ortelius his Theater of the vvorld, vvherein the principal regions of the earth are descrived in smalle mappes. VVith a brief declaration annexed to ech mappe. And donne in more exact manner, then lyke declarations in Latin, French, or other languages. It is also amplyfied with new mappes wanting in the Latin editions. Antwerp: Iohn Norton, 1601. STC 18857. ProQuest, https://www.proquest.com/books/epitome-ortelius-his-theater-vvorld-vvherein/docview/2240904399/se-2.Â
